_description: Sayings of Old Philosophers (or ‘Liber Prouerbium’ or ‘Summum Sapientie’) — 116 stanzas rhyme royal

BodAsh59.First Lines:
þE tyme approcheþe of necessite To reherce þe
                    material sentence Which þat to fore al equite Is þe
                    pryncipul of al sapience…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…þane after þis worlde transmygracoun In heven have
                    youre habitacyoun
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here folowen nowe þe seyinges of wysemen of Prophetes of Poetes of
                    Philosophres of hooly men of gret and Autorysed Clerkes of þe olde
                    testament and of þe nuwe (f. 84v)

BLHar2251.First Lines:
The tyme approached of necessiteTo reherse the marshal
                    sentence…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…And after worldly transmygratiounIn hevyns high have youre
                    habitacioun
BLHar2251.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Kleine Mitteilungen zur mittelenglische Lehrdichtung, VI.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         104 (1900): 293-309: 308 (stanzas 1-7).

BLHar7578.First Lines:
[T]he tyme approached of necessiteTo reherce the material
                    sentence…
BLHar7578.Last Lines:
…And after worldly transmygraciounIn heuyns high haue youre
                    habitacioun
BLHar7578.Note:
Preceded by a unique Prologue of 18 stanzas (5967). Initial
                    ‘T’ is missing, with space left for illuminated
                    initial.
BLHar7578.Editions:
Kniep,  R. M. 
             “Liber Pouerbium: An Edition of Middle English Proverbs Formerly
                Attributed to John Lydgate.” 
         Diss. University of Florida 1954 (DA 22.3185). 
Napierkowski,  T. J. 
             “A Critical Edition of the Summum Sapientiae.” 
         Diss. University of Colorado, 1971 (DA 32.2063A-64B).
